awd_titl_txt: Community Studies of Sociolinguistic Change in Appalachia
awd_abstract_narration:
The project's research questions focus on how traditional dialects have changed and how Appalachian teens alter them to build their own identities in the 21st century. Since World War II, rural America has changed dramatically, and sociolinguistic patterns in these communities have morphed over the last three generations. With these changes, English in Appalachia will be markedly different by the middle of the 21st century, and these transitions are socially and linguistically complex. This sociolinguistic confluence of change provides an excellent opportunity to examine why Appalachian teens propagate certain dialect features at the expense of others. This proposal provides worthwhile community benefits because it integrates research and education by advancing discovery and understanding of what language patterns hamper students from obtaining their fullest educational potential. The outcomes from the project will provide teachers across Appalachia with the content and pedagogical knowledge needed for addressing linguistic diversity in a culturally sustainable manner. The long-term objective is to boost students' comfort in the classroom by reducing 'stereotype threat' and fostering positive learning environments for students.
 
The proposed study brings together the previous examination of 14 variables and divergent West Virginia vowel systems to document emerging trends in language variation. The researchers will conduct interviews with Appalachian students to compare dialect patterns. The interviews will be in four schools in West Virginia: two northern, secondary schools (rural and nonrural) and two southern, secondary schools (rural and nonrural). The most socially marked variables from the previous studies provide lexical, morphological, and phonological variation for quantitative investigation. To probe deeper into teens' local understanding of sociolinguistic patterns, we will also conduct classroom observations and focus group discussions. The project design is well-suited to explore how teens use linguistic patterns to create social meanings that drive transmission and diffusion of Appalachian language variation patterns.

por.por_cntn:
English varieties in Appalachia are some of the most widely discussed dialects in the world. In contrast to their place in public lore, they have received relatively little empirical scholarly attention in comparison with other vernacular varieties. Work since the turn of the 21st century has attempted to rectify this situation. Over the last 25 years, the lead researcher and associates of the West Virginia Dialect Project (WVDP, 1998-2023) conducted 228 interviews with native Appalachians. From these interviews and through the three stages of the project, the WVDP has created several corpora of interviews to better study dialect variation in Appalachia.

For this final stage of this project, the sociolinguistic knowledge gained from the first two stages was applied in an analysis of language variation in changing Appalachian communities. As the United States transitions away from rural communities towards ever-larger suburban communities, the sociolinguistic landscape is changing, and along with it, English varieties in Appalachia. The first two stages provided a view of demographic groups and dialectological regions. This third stage follows the foundations of sociolinguistics in studying the influence of different language qualities on social awareness and educational identity. An early observation from linguists interested in social influences argues that: “the level of social awareness is a major property of linguistic change which must be determined directly. Subjective correlates of change are more categorical in nature than the changing patterns of behavior: their investigation deepens our understanding of the ways in which discrete categorization is imposed upon the continuous process of change” (Weinreich, Labov, and Herzog 1968:186). With a thorough knowledge of the diagnostic sociolinguistic variables garnered from the first two stages, the researchers on this project examined changes to sociolinguistic awareness, directions of language change and their motivations, as well as detailed the wider range of Appalachian sociolinguistic boundaries for the 21st century.  

In Appalachia, the more vernacular variants are the most impactful sociolinguistic makers. They show how speakers use language to identify different socioeconomic groups for communities. To better understand how these communities guide language change on the smallest level, it is important to understand how community members utilize language to steer themselves through different social groups and create their own identities. In our analysis of three grammar variables, we found significant results in both the individual interviews and the focus groups with our social variables. For example, the students with negative academic orientation used the vernacular variables more often in all environments. Strikingly, the male students with positive academic orientation utilized the vernacular variant more than the male students with negative academic orientation, apparently wanting to fit into every social circle. In the focus groups, where the conversation flowed freely, gender and academic orientation influenced vernacular variants. Male students with negative academic orientation avoided using supposedly feminine variants completely in every focus group. Only female students with negative academic orientation used vernacular variants during focus group discussions. Within the focus group discussions, students' social identities also influenced their own speech and perception of others’ speech. These patterns affect how teachers and other students understand these students, and the identities they craft fit differentially in the US educational system.

 

As part of the research efforts of the WVDP, we worked to determine the current status and directions of change for English in Appalachia, including the regional affiliations, the degrees of vernacularity, and the social divisions in dialects. This research led to numerous public outreach events, presentations, and reports that aim to educate the public on dialects and language variation and to destigmatize vernacular Appalachian features. 

 

Our research showed that many of the traditional features of English in Appalachia faded from WV, although some remain under the radar of social awareness. Because people use vowels to mark social differences, the most finely-grained and socially important language variation patterns in modern Appalachia are the ongoing changes to vowel systems. Another facet of this research is the examination of how changes to rural Appalachia are affecting the directions of language change. Rural areas in the United States transformed in the 20th century and  continue to evolve today. Our findings show that the language patterns of rural Americans reflect those changes. 

Beyond the public outreach efforts, the WVDP, through this grant, has provided invaluable training and scientific research experience for the Research Assistants who worked with the primary researchers. These students have gone on to become teachers, professional writers, data analysts, and human resource experts.

 

Overall, the work from this grant employed linguistic and educational analysis to enhance the description of language variation in the WV region of Appalachia. As a result of this NSF grant, English in Appalachia, one of the world’s best known varieties of English, now has several empirical studies of its language patterns.
